close_symbols: errno (extern / macro) and error macros: EINTR, EMSGSIZE, ETIMEDOUT
explanation:
To determine whether the target function uses any compiler or language extensions these symbols must be inspected because they can hide extensions that the function itself appears to use: 

- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET (macro): macros can employ compiler extensions (statement-expressions, typeof, GCC __extension__, inline asm, etc.). The macro body must be inspected to ensure no extensions are used.
- OS_impl_queue_table: the object the macro indexes into may be declared with attributes or placed in nonstandard sections via extensions; inspect its declaration.
- OS_object_token_t (typedef / definition): the token type definition could use compiler-specific attributes, anonymous/unnamed aggregates or nonstandard typedef constructs.
- OS_impl_queue_internal_record_t (typedef / definition): the record type is dereferenced (impl->id). Its struct/union definition may include anonymous/unnamed unions, compiler attributes, bit-field widths using extensions, or other nonstandard constructs.
- OSAL_SIZE_C (macro): this macro wraps size literals/casts and might use extensions (integer suffixes, typeof, statement expressions). Check its definition.
- OS_PEND, OS_CHECK, OS_QUEUE_INVALID_SIZE, OS_ERROR, OS_QUEUE_EMPTY, OS_QUEUE_TIMEOUT, OS_SUCCESS: constants/macros may be implemented via extension constructs (complex macros, attributes on enums, unusual integer literal forms). Their definitions must be checked.
- OS_Posix_CompAbsDelayTime (prototype/definition): although only called, its prototype/definition can introduce extension usage that affects how the target is compiled or used (e.g., nonstandard calling conventions, attributes).
- mq_receive and mq_timedreceive (prototypes): POSIX functions are normally standard, but platform headers could declare them with nonstandard attributes/macros or extensions; check their declarations.
- errno and error macros (EINTR, EMSGSIZE, ETIMEDOUT): errno handling may be a macro/inline function using thread-local storage or compiler-specific constructs; the error macros themselves may be defined via extensions on some platforms.
- ssize_t, size_t, int32 (typedefs): these integer type definitions may be aliases using compiler extensions (e.g., __int128 or compiler-specific typedefs) or macros that expand in nonstandard ways.
- struct timespec (definition): the struct definition could use anonymous unions or other extensions on some platforms; verify standard form.
- memset (prototype): ensure standard prototype (not a macro using extensions) since it is invoked here.

Inspecting these symbols will reveal whether any nonstandard language or compiler extensions are used (in macros, typedefs, prototypes, or struct definitions) that would cause a MISRA violation for using language extensions.
